Elementis PLC (ELM:LSE): Last: 271.80, up 16 (+6.25%), High: 282.00, Low: 263.80, Volume: 1.04m

BE11:14am

Everyone's been distracted by that talc thing they might buy, but probably won't because everyone shouted at them. And they've missed that Elementis has a mini Croda in the SOTP. That's the gist of it.

BE11:15am

Disclosure of EBIT by product category points to hidden value: At its H1
2018 results on 31 July, Elementis disclosed a new breakdown of earnings.
For the first time, “speciality products” was split into the components of
personal care, coatings and oilfield/energy. This step has been instructive
in unveiling the core value of the portfolio. For instance, the only personal
care business of substantial scale with higher EBIT margins than the
c26.5% made by Elementis is that of Croda, to our knowledge. We have
used the disclosure to generate a segment-by-segment SOTP. The market’s fixation on deal outcome is shown by the personal care segment trading at a near-chemicals-sector average 2018 multiple of just 13x EV/EBIT assuming cancellation of Mondo, relative to c25x for Croda.

red @Bryanmay become great again, anything is poss (however i doubt it becomes even relevant), but current shareholders unlikely to see abv 20 bucks for a long time.
BE11:16am

Berenberg put a 90% chance on Elementis walking away from Mondo.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

318p target on that eventuality, 288p target on the 10 per cent possibility that it presses on with the deal.

BE11:17am

We suspect that part of the disappointed reaction to the plastics-and-coatings focused Mondo deal is that it muddies the narrative on the
disproportionately fast growth of personal care, guided at c7% pa. On a
five-year view, assuming the deal does not complete, we expect the unique, 30%+ EBIT margin hectorite clays in Elementis’s legacy business to increase personal care’s contribution to EBIT from 38% to 43%. This is clearly inconsistent with a valuation at a 17% discount to two-year averages, and 7% to the industrials-dominated SX4p. The higher multiples associated with the earnings shift could drive a blue-sky scenario with c50% upside.

BE11:25am

An operationally challenging 1H18 has seen an even more challenging set of financials as EBITDA missed our forecast by 9%. This is in part owing
to what appears to be a burgeoning trend through this reporting period of central costs coming in higher than we were looking for ($35m of the $86m miss). The EBITDA at Centinela was $229m far below our $300m – this will require more investigation as it's a striking amount of variance considering the cash costs by mine were pre-reported (Pelambres and Antucoya offset in part to the upside – this is likely due to embedded provisions). Extra tax paid and the lower cash flow from operations pushed net debt to $781m vs. RBC at $609.7m. The lower EPS 19.6 cents vs RBC at 24.7 cents led to a commensurately lower interim dividend at 6.8 cents vs. RBC at 8.6 cents.
The shares are likely to struggle this morning, but certainly helping to offset the negative sentiment is the reiteration of production and cost guidance (assuming the CLP and the molybdenum price stay at current levels). There is likely an implicit downgrade in this context from the sense that the CLPUSD is at 660, well above the ~600 levels at the time of the full-year results, however Moly prices are well ahead of these levels too. The guidance has been one of improving grades in 2H18, driving improved performance, and we note we are already forecasting below the 705-740kt (RBC 686kt) at net cash costs of $1.35/lb (RBC $1.46/lb). For now, this is likely to be the bad news out in the price. At 5.5x spot 2019 EV/EBITDA, the shares remain relatively fully priced. We reiterate our Sector Perform rating.

red @ cheeckychappyits like judgement day, it was always going to happen. when you accept this you can then prepare and even profit from it.
cheeckychappy @red - mmm, maybe - there is a big social/political movement to stop Brexit, so not so sure...
BE11:26am

And Morgan Stanley.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

We see limited scope for self-driven earnings enhancements that could drive positive earnings surprises. Moreover, the company's mine profile implies falling grades in the medium-term and faces rising rock hardness, which should accelerate unit cost inflation. Our concern is that Antofagasta will need to spend substantial capital to sustain production, which would continue to be a drag on FCF. Against this backdrop, a meaningful increase in LT copper prices is needed to justify the returns on the company's investments, in our view. Shares are pricing in a copper price of ~US$2.8/lb, we believe, thus offering little safety margin.

cheeckychappy also whilst there aint no buyers of London stock there aren't too many sellers, too. I mean the flat I got called on was on the market last year!
red thats what they said 2 years ago. and look where we are now. nothing agreed bar the divorce. and do you think the folks of the uk will want may to pay up 50 yards if there is no deal to go with it?
Manxish Morning each
cheeckychappy 50 yards? What's that?
BE11:28am

Chris Lafemina at Jefferies is more positive around the longer term.

BE11:28am

Recent weakness in the copper price (oddly) coincides with declining exchange inventories and the risk of an imminent strike at the Escondida mine, which accounts for about 5% of global copper supply. While demand continues to be relatively strong according to most mining companies, China macro data is weakening, the potential impact of trade wars on global growth is unclear, the Fed is raising interest rates, and the US dollar is strengthening. We expect the copper price to recover heading into 2019 on the back of worsening supply constraints and some recovery in Chinese demand due to more accommodative monetary and fiscal policy. However, we are more concerned about copper price risk than operational risk for Anto as we believe the company will hit its full year guidance but we are less confident in the macro outlook.

red mkts are just beginning to squeeze certain assets, the main proxy eurgbp, no to around 90 cents. look for this to move to parity/1.05. then you can safely get back in to back uk assets imo

The political threat can only get worse… with a Brexit & Labour risk.

BE11:36am

Political risks:
The one positive support has been Help to Buy, and though this has been extended, from here we see a growing political risk in the
following areas:
 Reduction in tax credits on buy to let. Already the income tax credit on mortgage payments is gradually being phased to the basic
rate of income tax (by 2021).
 Increased pressure to build social housing. The Conservatives have already announced a plan to provide £2bn additional funding for
the government's 2016-21 affordable housing programme, which could result in supply of 25,000 homes for social rent.
 The Labour government risk. This would potentially result in a Mansion/Land Value Tax (former leader Ed Miliband supported a
mansion tax on homes over £2m and the current Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has proposed replacing council tax with a LVT). We
also suspect that property developers could face much higher development charges and taxes under a Labour government; at the
last party conference, leader Jeremy Corbyn said “We need to tax undeveloped land held by developers and have the power to
compulsorily purchase”.

BE11:36am

Brexit and labour shortage risks:
 The housebuilders would be particularly vulnerable to any sharp tightening
in EU labour regulations. There are increasingly signs of labour shortages
in the housing sector, and housing construction cost inflation is closely
related to construction wage growth.
 UK construction sector employs about 200k EU nationals, according to
RICS, equivalent to 8% of the sector's total workforce. Any disruption from
Brexit to the status of EU nationals would be unhelpful.

red i wouldnt worry about it too much, just mop up whats avaliable after, use the eurgbp as a proxy for calling the bottom.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

The first-half results saw the group post a small (-4.6%) decline in
underlying PBT, mainly as a result of the poor weather impact in March/April combined with other delays on commercial/infrastructure activity. Residential Systems continues to perform better (revenue +5.9%) than Commercial (-6.6%) products, due in large part to the strong new build housing market. Residential rmi activity/markets remain tricky. The poor weather combined with some delays in road projects were behind the softer commercial figures, while some pressures from higher raw material and transport costs also held profits back in both end markets.

BE11:46am

The shares have slipped by c10% ytd, marginally worse than the building materials group average. In valuation terms they are now trading on an undemanding PE of 12.5x for 2018 and 11.7x for 2019, with a free cash flow yield of 10.3% and 8.8%, respectively. The dividend yield is also a respectable 3.4% for the current year. We continue to see these valuations for a market-leading business, which is set to benefit from increased housing output and regulation change (especially on water/drainage) over the medium term. Remains a Buy with a target price of 465p.

Penny @cheeky - what percentage reduction did that represent, and was it new build ?
BE11:47am

Peel Hunt also pro Hill & Smith, seeing yesterday's 25% drop as silly.

11:47 am
Hill & Smith Holdings PLC (HILS:LSE): Last: 1,101, up 67 (+6.48%), High: 1,105, Low: 1,007, Volume: 132.40k
BE11:47am

After a tough Q1 impacted by bad weather and commodity price volatility we are downgrading our forecasts for FY18E and FY19E. The share price reaction seems totally out of proportion, in our view, and we see this as a compelling buying opportunity. The miss just reminds us that after a phenomenal five-year spell, HILS is not bullet-proof, so we are basing our revised 1,380p TP on a PER multiple of 17.5x FY19E rather than 19x, which implies some 27% upside from here.

cheeckychappy @Penny - it was between 3pc and 5pc reduction and it was period property - late Victorian.
BE11:48am

Hang on, not yesterday, The days are blurring together.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Anyway, they're both in the same markets pretty much but Hill & Smith is exposed to zinc costs so had to cut guidance and Polypipe isn't so doesn't.

DRichi @Cheeky - that's minimal reduction. In my part of London asking prices have dropped 20-25% since last year.
BE11:50am

The share price reaction (more than 25% down) to what is effectively a c9% downgrade seems totally out of proportion, in our view, and more in keeping with a company who’s business model is broken, or for which an entire end-market has evaporated – neither of which is the case. The only difference we can see between the investment case as it was last Tuesday evening and the investment case now is that we have been reminded, after a superb and transformational five-year spell, that HILS is not bullet-proof to external factors.

undefined

Should mention Esure, since the bid that leaked early doors yesterday is now confirmed.

esure Group PLC (ESUR:LSE): Last: 277.90, up 10.7 (+4.00%), High: 278.60, Low: 276.60, Volume: 23.61m

Looks done, given Sir Peter wants out and other shareholders seem happy. Very little chance of a counter one would have thought given the semi-public sale process (though there was a bit of an attempt by traders to put RSA's name into the mix yesterday, which seems very highly speculative.)

Soundbuy Polypiep -bit of a moat as produces pipes in imperial units, no overseas competitor does (plus full of air!)

sparrowhawk @BE are we likely to see more P2P activity by the PE players?
Soundbuy *polypipe
11:54 am
BE11:54am

The arbs at Olivetree think this one's going to be walked off from here.

DRichi Seeing lots of price drops from circa 500k - 400k
BE11:54am

This looks a very straightforward deal. Of course we are pleased to see yet another esoteric rule of the takeover code come into play in order to approve the special arrangements with Peter Wood, but these arrangements are highly likely to be approved by shareholders. Strong irrevocables from Tosca and Wood’s involvement going forward make it somewhat unlikely that a counter is received here. esure has had a torrid time recently and shareholders are likely to welcome a bid pitched at 37% premium to the previous close having endured an almost 30% drop year to date. Today’s results have done little to paint a rosier picture going forward. Timing should be about 4 months, in keeping with previous insurance deals, and none of the conditions is likely to cause any problems – this will largely be process. We would expect this to trade tight, but feel the likelihood of a counter here is remote.

BE11:55am

Worth nothing also that Esure results today are rubbish.

[W]e highlight that the UK motor market is price elastic, and competitive. With shop around levels at 2/3 of the market, this can limit attractions to would be buyers, particularly given longer term structural threats from technology. Given this dynamic, the strategic / financial rationale for Bain Capital is not obvious, in our view.

Excel Developer Southwark also experiencing major price falls.
BE11:59am

Citi can answer that!

BE11:59am

Sort of.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Bain Capital Private Equity has a portfolio of over 800 investments with total AUM of c.a. $95bn. It seeks to leverage a shared platform to capture cross-asset opportunities - although there are few obvious other insurance companies in the portfolio currently. It has a consultancy-based approach to PE investing, partnering with management teams to improve operationally. The parent, Bain & Company, is a leading management consultancy with significant insurance expertise in digital and customer-centricity.

BE12:00pm

The addition of such knowledge to Esure should make it a stronger player in UK retail P&C at a time when operational delivery has been somewhat slow-paced. We don’t think that this heralds the start of further consolidation in the sector given generally stronger delivery and focus at peers. While Direct Line, Hastings and Admiral are all trading up in sympathy ultimately we see this development as a negative for incumbents given Esure’s likely enhanced capabilities. We believe that low cost motor insurance through price comparison will continue to be commoditised and mono-line insurers need to significantly improve customer propositions and widen their product ranges. This increasingly demands superior IT implementation and execution.
